item.title: Color the Muscles of the Head and Neck
item.dc:creator: Shannan Muskopf
item.description:
Students practice naming the muscles of the head with this simple coloring worksheet. Image shows the major superficial muscles with numbers. If you download the Google Doc, it will also include the answer key. There are two versions in this file. One has the numbers and names given and students just color it. There is a more difficult version included where students must identify the muscles and fill in the numbers. I also have a coloring activity I do with students where we go over the names and they label a diagram and color as we go. In this version,

The post Color the Muscles of the Head and Neck first appeared on The Biology Corner.

item.title: Light Independent Reaction and Calvin Cycle
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.description:
In my advanced biology classes, students take a closer look at photosynthesis. You can view a simpler version of this photosynthesis activity here. This worksheet helps to reinforce concepts presented in the class lecture. The graphic is also embedded within the slides so that you can pause and have students practice labeling before continuing to the Calvin Cycle. The first graphic on this worksheet is the basic overview of the light dependent reaction and the Calvin cycle.. It focuses on the general reactants and products of each reaction. In the second graphic, students take a closer look at the light

The post Light Independent Reaction and Calvin Cycle first appeared on The Biology Corner.

item.title: How Did the Cardinal Get His Red Feathers (CER)
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.description:
Have you ever seen a beautiful red cardinal in your backyard? This bird is so striking that seven states list it as their state bird. Red coloration is not that common in nature, seen mainly in flowers and birds and some fur colors. The red coloration is the result of carotenoids that have been converted to ketocarotenoids by enzymes. The mechanism is complex and involves several intermediaries. This short explanation is based on a study from Nature with a simplified graphic to illustrate how enzymes are involved. There are several genes that work together to express red coloration. These genes

The post How Did the Cardinal Get His Red Feathers (CER) first appeared on The Biology Corner.
